qas.question: What is the effective f-number proportional to?

answers.text: the ratio between the lens focal length and aperture diameter

qas.question: What is used to discover the right exposure parameters?
What variables help the photographer produce the desired effect?

answers.text: lighting, film speed, f-number (aperture size), and shutter speed (exposure time)

qas.question: A lens with a setting of f/1.4 lets how much to hit the focal plane compared with a setting of f/2?
In the APEX system, the increment that doubles the exposure is called what?
What are appropriate exposure parameters used to find?
What is another name for film speed?
The ratio between the diameter and square root of the aperture is called what?
How much does light does an f/2 let in as compared to an f/4?

context: <a1_0><b5_0>Film speed<b5_0/><a1_0/> is used in the exposure equations to find the appropriate exposure parameters. Four variables are available to the photographer to obtain the desired effect: <a2_0>lighting, film speed, f-number (aperture size), and shutter speed (exposure time)<a2_0/>. The equation may be expressed as ratios, or, by taking the logarithm (base 2) of both sides, by addition, using the <b7_0>APEX<b7_0/> system, in which every increment of 1 is a doubling of exposure; this increment is commonly known as a <a4_0>"<b6_0>stop<b6_0/>"<a4_0/>. The <b8_0>effective f-number<b8_0/> is proportional to <a0_0>the ratio between the lens focal length and aperture diameter<a0_0/>, the diameter itself being proportional to the square root of the aperture area. Thus, a lens set to f/1.4 allows <a3_0><b9_0>twice as much<b9_0/><a3_0/> light to strike the focal plane as a lens set to f/2. Therefore, each f-number factor of the square root of two (approximately 1.4) is also a stop, so lenses are typically marked in that progression: f/1.4, 2, 2.8, 4, 5.6, 8, 11, 16, 22, 32, etc.
